content.title: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
content.summary: Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is the most common entrapment neuropathy, caused by compression of the median nerve at the wrist within the carpal tunnel. It presents with nocturnal paresthesias in the median nerve distribution and, if severe, thenar weakness. Diagnosis is clinical with NCS/EMG confirmation. Treatment ranges from splinting to surgical release.
key_points: Most common entrapment neuropathy; median nerve compression at wrist
Classic presentation: nocturnal hand numbness/tingling awakening patient
Sensory symptoms in thumb, index, middle, and radial half of ring finger
Phalen test (wrist flexion) and Tinel sign (tapping over carpal tunnel) are provocative
NCS shows prolonged distal sensory latency across the wrist
Splinting for mild-moderate; carpal tunnel release for severe or refractory
content.statement: Carpal tunnel syndrome is compression of the median nerve at the wrist causing sensory symptoms in the median distribution and thenar weakness when severe, diagnosed clinically and confirmed by NCS, and treated with splinting or surgical decompression.

explanation.intuition: The carpal tunnel is like a crowded subway car with the median nerve as one passenger. When the tunnel gets even slightly smaller (inflammation, fluid, repetitive strain), the nerve gets squeezed. This causes the classic symptoms of numbness and tingling, worse at night because wrist position during sleep further compresses the tunnel.
explanation.key_insight: Nocturnal symptoms are the key clinical clue: patients wake at night shaking their hands to relieve numbness ('flick sign'). This happens because wrist flexion during sleep narrows the carpal tunnel. Weakness is a late finding indicating severe compression with axonal loss.
explanation.technical_details: The carpal tunnel is bounded by carpal bones and the transverse carpal ligament. Contents: 9 flexor tendons + median nerve. Any space-occupying process or volume increase causes nerve compression. NCS shows prolonged distal sensory latency (>3.5ms) and prolonged distal motor latency (>4.2ms) across the wrist.

definitions_glossary.carpal_tunnel_syndrome: Median nerve entrapment at the wrist within the carpal tunnel
definitions_glossary.median_nerve: Mixed sensory/motor nerve; sensory to thumb, index, middle, radial ring; motor to thenar muscles
definitions_glossary.carpal_tunnel: Fibro-osseous tunnel at wrist formed by carpal bones and transverse carpal ligament
definitions_glossary.thenar_muscles: Abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, superficial head of flexor pollicis brevis
definitions_glossary.Phalen_test: Wrist flexion for 60 seconds; positive if symptoms reproduced
definitions_glossary.Tinel_sign: Tapping over carpal tunnel; positive if paresthesias elicited
definitions_glossary.flick_sign: Patient shakes/flicks hand to relieve nocturnal symptoms
definitions_glossary.NCS: Nerve conduction study; measures sensory and motor latencies
definitions_glossary.distal_sensory_latency: Time for sensory signal to travel across wrist; prolonged in CTS
definitions_glossary.thenar_atrophy: Wasting of thenar eminence from severe/chronic CTS
definitions_glossary.carpal_tunnel_release: CTR; surgical division of transverse carpal ligament

pathophysiology.mechanism: Median nerve compression within the rigid carpal tunnel
contributing_factors: Decreased tunnel size: thickened ligament, bone spurs, fracture malunion
Increased tunnel contents: tenosynovitis, ganglion, lipoma
Systemic conditions: pregnancy, hypothyroidism, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, amyloidosis, acromegaly

pathology_progression.late: Axonal loss causing weakness and atrophy (less reversible)

sensory_symptoms: Numbness and tingling in median distribution (thumb, index, middle, radial ring)
Nocturnal symptoms waking patient from sleep
Symptoms relieved by shaking hand (flick sign)
motor_symptoms: Thenar weakness (late finding): weak thumb abduction and opposition
Difficulty with fine motor tasks (buttons, writing)

Phalen_test.technique: Hold wrists fully flexed for 60 seconds

Tinel_sign.technique: Tap over median nerve at carpal tunnel

carpal_compression_test.technique: Direct pressure over carpal tunnel for 30 seconds

NCS_EMG.indication: Confirm diagnosis, assess severity, rule out other diagnoses

findings.sensory: Prolonged distal sensory latency (>3.5ms) or reduced amplitude
findings.EMG: Denervation in thenar muscles (fibrillations, positive sharp waves) in severe cases

differential_diagnosis: Cervical radiculopathy (C6/C7; neck pain, reflex loss)
Pronator syndrome (forearm pain, no nocturnal worsening)

wrist_splinting.timing: Night-time use; can extend to daytime if needed

conservative_management.activity_modification: Avoid repetitive wrist motion, ergonomic adjustments

corticosteroid_injection.technique: Injection into carpal tunnel (avoid median nerve)
corticosteroid_injection.efficacy: 70-90% short-term relief; benefit may wane over months
corticosteroid_injection.limit: 2-3 injections; bridge to surgery if recurrent

post_operative: Weakness and atrophy may not fully recover if long-standing

definition.@value: The most common entrapment neuropathy, caused by compression of the median nerve at the wrist within the carpal tunnel

scopeNote.@value: Covers clinical diagnosis, NCS confirmation, conservative treatment with splinting, and surgical release indications

medicalCode.description: Carpal tunnel syndrome, unspecified upper limb

learning_objectives: Recognize the classic presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome
Perform and interpret Phalen and Tinel tests
Interpret NCS findings in carpal tunnel syndrome
Identify indications for surgical carpal tunnel release
clinical_pearls: Nocturnal awakening + flick sign = highly suggestive of CTS
Median sensory spares the palm (palmar cutaneous branch exits proximal to tunnel)
Thenar atrophy = severe, longstanding CTS; needs surgery
Check for diabetes and hypothyroidism in bilateral CTS
Surgery has >90% success rate for properly selected patients
common_misconceptions: CTS always requires surgery - most improve with splinting
Negative NCS rules out CTS - clinical diagnosis can stand with typical presentation
CTS only affects typists - many systemic causes including pregnancy, hypothyroidism
